title: Moon Area school board takes public comment on Cornell merger, political talk emerges
text:
Larger font size Posted: Monday, October 12, 2015 10:00 pm Moon Area school board takes public comment on Cornell merger, political talk emerges By Katherine Schaeffer kschaeffer@timesonline.com Timesonline.com | 0 comments 
MOON TWP. — Politics overshadowed public comment about a potential merger between Moon Area and Cornell school districts at Moon Area’s board meeting Monday night. 
About 70 Moon and Coraopolis community members gathered in the Moon Area Middle School auditorium to share a range of perspectives about a plan to merge starting next school year, proposed by Moon Superintendent Curt Baker at the board’s Oct. 5 meeting. 
Four Cornell district residents stood up to encourage the board to consider the merger, and several Moon Area residents expressed concern about the suggested three-week time frame, with some pointing out a potential political agenda behind the unorthodox proposal. 
The public comment session and an additional presentation about the merger from Baker remained on the Oct. 12 agenda, despite a statement Cornell Superintendent Aaron Thomas released Oct. 6, denouncing Baker’s plan for its hurried time frame, questionable motives and dubious legality. 
Baker had prepared a second presentation with “additional information” about the merger for the Oct. 12 meeting, but it was voted off the agenda with a 4-3 vote after a motion from board member Jerry Testa. 
Testa said he believed the presentation should be omitted from the meeting because Cornell School District had “repeatedly and emphatically stated ‘no’ ” to the merger. 
“Hopefully this kills this crazy idea of merging within a couple weeks and dissolving school boards,” he said. 
Baker outlined the administration’s plan for a potential merger at the district’s Oct. 5 board meeting. 
The proposal called for the districts to merge starting in fall 2016. Both boards would dissolve before the November election, meaning that the merger would need to be approved by Oct. 31. 
The Allegheny Intermediate Unit would take over school board duties and oversee the merger until a new board is elected in April. 
The plan was met with backlash from some community members, including incoming school board members like James Bogotay, who say they believe Baker’s plan is a ploy to prevent them from taking their seats in December. 
The five newcomers have been vocally opposed to several of the current school board’s decisions, including the Moon elementary school reconfiguration and closing of Hyde Elementary School. 
“The issue today is not about how Moon Township residents see Cornell residents,” Bogotay said. “This has nothing to do with the kids, sadly. It’s 100 percent political.” 
But some Cornell School District parents, like Beth Haus, of Neville Island, said they could overlook politics in favor of opportunities for their children. 
Haus, whose two sons attend school in the district, said if a merger could be agreed upon in two weeks, she would welcome it. 
“I have no concern whatsoever for self-serving politics,” she said. “All the children deserve the same kind of education that this merger would allow for.” 
The discussion divided Moon’s school board as well, with board member Dennis Harbaugh acknowledging the benefits of a merger, but admitting that the three-week time frame would be “absurd.” 
“When I see an opportunity to help kids, it does hit me,” Harbaugh said. 
Board member Gia Tatone, who wrote a book about the history of Coraopolis, argued in favor of hearing community input, citing historical examples of mergers between the two districts being revisited over the decades. 
Board member Michael Hauser said he is not opposed to the merger that would benefit the children, but is more comfortable revisiting the topic once the new board is seated. 
Incoming school board members Bogotay and Mark Scappe say they agree with Hauser. 
Scappe, a Cornell High School graduate who served on Moon’s school board when the districts considered merging in 1998, said he remembers the crucial planning and extensive community feedback involved. 
The districts must consider teachers union organization, state funding, integrating curricula, sports and transportation among other things, Scappe said. 
“That was 16 years ago, and it didn’t work out that time,” he said. “However times change, things change and I have no opposition to revisiting it.“
